slides.title: Welcome to Materials Science
slides.content:
# Introduction to Materials Science

Welcome to **Materials Science** - understanding matter!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Material Properties** - Strength, ductility
- **Material Types** - Metals, polymers, ceramics
- **Nanomaterials** - Very small scale
- **Composites** - Combining materials
- **Degradation** - Failure and corrosion

> **Fun Fact:** Graphene is just one atom thick but 200 times stronger than steel!

slides.title: Mechanical Properties
slides.content:
# Mechanical Properties

## Key Properties:

| Property | Definition |
|----------|------------|
| Strength | Resistance to deformation |
| Hardness | Resistance to indentation |
| Ductility | Ability to deform without breaking |
| Toughness | Energy absorption before fracture |
| Stiffness | Resistance to elastic deformation |
| Fatigue | Failure under cyclic loading |

## Stress-Strain:
- Elastic region (reversible)
- Yield point
- Plastic region (permanent)
- Ultimate strength
- Fracture

slides.title: Types of Materials
slides.content:
# Types of Materials

## Four Classes:

| Type | Examples | Properties |
|------|----------|------------|
| Metals | Steel, aluminum | Strong, conductive |
| Polymers | Plastic, rubber | Light, flexible |
| Ceramics | Glass, alumina | Hard, brittle |
| Composites | Fiberglass, carbon fiber | Tailored properties |

## Bonding Types:
- Metallic: Electron sea
- Ionic: Charge transfer
- Covalent: Electron sharing
- Van der Waals: Weak attraction

## Selection:
- Application requirements
- Cost considerations
- Processing capability

slides.title: Metals and Alloys
slides.content:
# Metals and Alloys

## Pure Metals:
- Good conductors
- Often soft
- Ductile

## Alloys:
- Mixtures of metals
- Improved properties

## Common Alloys:

| Alloy | Components | Use |
|-------|------------|-----|
| Steel | Iron + carbon | Construction |
| Stainless | Steel + chromium | Food, medical |
| Brass | Copper + zinc | Fittings |
| Bronze | Copper + tin | Bearings |
| Titanium alloy | Ti + Al + V | Aerospace |

## Heat Treatment:
- Annealing, quenching, tempering
- Change microstructure
- Alter properties

slides.title: Polymers
slides.content:
# Polymers

## Structure:
- Long chain molecules
- Repeating units (monomers)

## Types:

| Type | Properties | Example |
|------|------------|--------|
| Thermoplastic | Melt and reform | PE, PVC, PP |
| Thermoset | Permanent shape | Epoxy, polyester |
| Elastomer | Stretchy, return | Rubber |

## Properties:
- Low density
- Good insulators
- Chemically resistant
- Variable strength

## Processing:
- Injection molding
- Extrusion
- Blow molding
- 3D printing

slides.title: Ceramics
slides.content:
# Ceramics

## Characteristics:
- Inorganic, non-metallic
- Hard but brittle
- High melting point
- Good insulators

## Types:

| Type | Examples | Use |
|------|----------|-----|
| Traditional | Clay, porcelain | Pottery |
| Engineering | Alumina, silicon carbide | Tools, abrasives |
| Glass | Soda-lime, borosilicate | Windows, containers |
| Cement | Portland cement | Construction |

## Applications:
- Cutting tools
- Thermal barriers
- Electronics (insulators)
- Biomedical implants

slides.title: Composites
slides.content:
# Composite Materials

## Definition:
Two or more materials combined for enhanced properties.

## Components:
- Matrix: Continuous phase
- Reinforcement: Embedded phase

## Types:

| Composite | Matrix | Reinforcement |
|-----------|--------|---------------|
| Fiberglass | Polymer | Glass fibers |
| CFRP | Polymer | Carbon fiber |
| Metal matrix | Metal | Ceramic particles |
| Concrete | Cement | Aggregate |

## Advantages:
- High strength-to-weight
- Tailored properties
- Corrosion resistance

## Applications:
- Aerospace structures
- Sports equipment
- Wind turbine blades

slides.title: Nanomaterials
slides.content:
# Nanomaterials

## Definition:
Materials with features at nanoscale (1-100 nm).

## Types:

| Type | Dimension |
|------|----------|
| Nanoparticles | 0D (all nano) |
| Nanotubes/wires | 1D |
| Nanosheets | 2D |
| Nanocomposites | Nano in bulk |

## Key Materials:
- Carbon nanotubes
- Graphene
- Quantum dots
- Nano-silver

## Properties:
- High surface area
- Quantum effects
- Enhanced strength
- Different behavior than bulk

slides.title: Corrosion
slides.content:
# Corrosion

## Definition:
Degradation of material due to environment.

## Types:

| Type | Description |
|------|-------------|
| Uniform | Even attack |
| Galvanic | Two different metals |
| Pitting | Localized holes |
| Crevice | Narrow gaps |
| Stress | Under stress |

## Prevention:
- Protective coatings
- Cathodic protection
- Material selection
- Corrosion inhibitors
- Galvanizing (zinc coating)

## Corrosion Rate:
- Affected by environment
- pH, temperature, chemicals

slides.title: Material Failure
slides.content:
# Material Failure

## Failure Modes:

| Mode | Cause |
|------|-------|
| Ductile | Gradual deformation |
| Brittle | Sudden fracture |
| Fatigue | Cyclic loading |
| Creep | High temperature, time |
| Wear | Surface contact |

## Fatigue:
- S-N curve
- Crack initiation and growth
- Stress concentration

## Creep:
- Time-dependent deformation
- High temperature
- Three stages

## Analysis:
- Fractography
- Root cause analysis

slides.title: Material Testing
slides.content:
# Material Testing

## Mechanical Tests:

| Test | Measures |
|------|----------|
| Tensile | Strength, ductility |
| Hardness | Surface hardness |
| Impact | Toughness |
| Fatigue | Cyclic life |
| Creep | Time-dependent deformation |

## Non-Destructive Testing (NDT):
- X-ray radiography
- Ultrasonic testing
- Magnetic particle
- Dye penetrant

## Microstructure:
- Optical microscopy
- Electron microscopy
- X-ray diffraction

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Materials Science Summary

## Material Types:
| Type | Key Property |
|------|-------------|
| Metals | Strong, conductive |
| Polymers | Light, flexible |
| Ceramics | Hard, brittle |
| Composites | Tailored |

## Properties:
- Strength, hardness, ductility
- Stress-strain behavior

## Advanced Materials:
- Nanomaterials
- Carbon fiber composites

## Degradation:
- Corrosion (chemical)
- Fatigue (mechanical)
- Creep (thermal)

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Materials Science!
